headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to today's Oracle Corp. Quarterly Conference. Today's call is being recorded and now at this time, I'd like to introduce Ken Bond, Vice President of Investor Relations, Oracle. Please go ahead.
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to today's Oracle Corp. Quarterly Conference. Today's call is being recorded and now at this time, I'd like to introduce Ken Bond, Vice President of Investor Relations, Oracle. Please go ahead.

headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Anthony, and good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to Oracle's First Quarter and Fiscal Year 2012 Earnings Conference Call. A copy of the press release and financial tables, which includes a GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliation and other supplementa
componenttext:
Thank you, Anthony, and good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to Oracle's First Quarter and Fiscal Year 2012 Earnings Conference Call. A copy of the press release and financial tables, which includes a GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliation and other supplemental financial information can be viewed and downloaded from our Investor Relations website. 
On the call today are Chief Executive Officer, Larry Ellison; President and CFO, Safra Catz; and President, Mark Hurd. As a reminder, today's discussion will include forward-looking statements including predictions, expectations, estimates or other information that might be considered forward-looking. Throughout today's discussion, we will attempt to present some important factors relating to our business, which may potentially affect these forward-looking statements. While these forward-looking statements represent our current judgment, the statements are also subject to risks and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ materially from statements being made today. As a result, we caution you against placing undue reliance on these forward-looking statements. And we encourage you to review our most recent reports on Forms 10-K and 10-Q and any applicable amendments for a complete discussion of these factors and other risks that may affect our future results or the market price of our stock. And finally, we're not obligating ourselves to revise our results or publicly release any revisions of these forward-looking statements in light of new information or future events. Before taking questions in the audience, we will begin with a few prepared remarks. And with that, I'd like to turn the call over to Safra.

headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ken. I'm going to focus on our non-GAAP results for Q1. I'll then review guidance for Q2 and then turn the call over to Larry and Mark for their comments. As you can see, we delivered another great quarter as we executed well throughout the quar
componenttext:
Thanks, Ken. I'm going to focus on our non-GAAP results for Q1. I'll then review guidance for Q2 and then turn the call over to Larry and Mark for their comments. 
As you can see, we delivered another great quarter as we executed well throughout the quarter, including late July and August. Our Q1 results against our June guidance made clear that we continue to have a lot of company-specific momentum. Obviously, we're pleased with the results. Our New Software license revenue was up 17% to $1.5 billion building an exceptional growth of 25% in Q1 of last year. We continue to see broad-based geographic and product momentum at Technology and License revenues were up 14% to $1.1 billion and Applications grew 23% this quarter to $428 million with Europe particularly strong. Geographically, the quarter was balanced with New License growing 10% in the Americas, 20% in APAC and 25% in EMEA. 
The quarter was also not dependent on any large deals. Software License Update and Product Support revenues were up 16% to $4 billion. Reported tax and renewal rates continue at the usual high level. Hardware Systems revenue was $1 billion for the quarter. This quarter, Hardware growth margins were 54%, significantly higher than the 48% last year as we continue to ship the product mix to more profitable products and engineered systems and as we continue to improve our supply chain efficiencies. 
Total revenues for the quarter was $8.4 billion, up 11% from last year. We matched this topline momentum with business discipline and we're extremely pleased with our non-GAAP operating income of $3.6 billion, 21% higher than last year as our operating margin expanded to 42% from 39% last year. 
We still believe there remains ample leverage in our business model and we could be back at our pre-Sun operating margins quite quickly. The non-GAAP tax rates for the quarter was 26.5%. EPS for the quarter grew 14% to $0.48 on a non-GAAP basis. 
I'll tell you that really being able to put up these topline and bottom-line results given our size once again demonstrates the real strength of our product line, the loyalty of our customer base and the strength of the operating model. We have the products in the market that customers want to buy. And OpenWorld, which starts next month will only make us even more obvious. 
Operating cash flow increased to a record $12.8 billion over the last 4 quarters with operating cash flow increasing this quarter to $5.4 billion, up $1.6 billion from $3.8 billion in Q1 of last year. Free cash flow grew 46% to a record $12.3 billion over the last 4 quarters. We now have nearly $32 billion in cash and marketable securities. 
Now as we said, we are committed to returning value to our shareholders through technical innovation, strategic acquisition, stock repurchases, prudent use of debt, and the dividend and we'll continue to be opportunistic. This quarter, we repurchased 27.5 million shares. And the Board of Directors declared our quarterly dividend of $0.06 per share. 
Now to the guidance. And as many of you remember, we had a great second quarter last year with New License up 21% on a non-GAAP basis and up 33%. And GAAP EPS up 27%. So let me just say that again. New License was up 21%, non-GAAP EPS was up 33% and GAAP EPS was up 27%. So those are pretty tough comparisons and we don't expect much help from currency because at this point, it looks like only 1% is where it is. 
New Software license revenue growth is expected to range from 6% to 16% in growth. Hardware product revenue growth is expected to range from flat to negative 5%. However, we do expect gross margins and profitability of our overall Hardware business to improve during the quarter as we continue to move away from selling low-margin commodity server and focus on selling engineered systems like Exadata, Exalogic and SPARC Solaris system. 
Total revenue growth on a non-GAAP basis is expected to range from 4% to 8%. On a GAAP basis, we expect total revenue growth of 5% to 9%. Non-GAAP EPS is expected to be somewhere between $0.56 and $0.58, up from $0.51 last year. GAAP EPS is expected to be $0.44 and $0.46. This guidance is been to GAAP and non-GAAP tax rate of 27%, of course, it may end up being different. With that, I'll turn it over to Larry for his comments.

headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Safra. In Q1 we transition away from selling low-margin commodity servers to selling high-margin engineering systems, increasing both the gross margins and the overall profitability of our Hardware business. In Q2, we will accelerate that trend
componenttext:
Thank you, Safra. In Q1 we transition away from selling low-margin commodity servers to selling high-margin engineering systems, increasing both the gross margins and the overall profitability of our Hardware business. In Q2, we will accelerate that trend when we introduce 4 brand-new engineered systems products. Each of these new engineered systems ultimately combine Oracle Software, Oracle Silicon and Oracle Hardware to deliver extreme high-performing, all tolerance high reliability and improved ease-of-use. 
The large of these engineered systems is the full tolerance, SPARC Supercluster, featuring our new SPARC T4 microprocessor that runs up to 5x faster than a T3 microprocessor that replace it. Our new feature-rich Solaris 11 operating system and the ultra high-performance Exadata Flash disk storage system. The SPARC Supercluster runs the Oracle Database Applications faster and less expensively than anything available from IBM. Thus, we expect that many customers in our large SPARC Solaris install base will be upgradign to SPARC supercluster's. Mark, it's all yours.

headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Larry. Just a few points on the quarter, you heard about 17% growth. That comes on top of 25% last year. It was primarily organic broad-based across Tech and Apps, both growing double digits. Performance across geographies was balanced. One number
componenttext:
Thanks, Larry. Just a few points on the quarter, you heard about 17% growth. That comes on top of 25% last year. It was primarily organic broad-based across Tech and Apps, both growing double digits. Performance across geographies was balanced. One number worth noting was Apps in Europe was up over 60%, 6-0 percent. 
Second. Exadata Exalogic. Year-to-date growth was nearly triple digit, broad-based across industries and geographies and we sold systems to more than 150 unique customers of which 100 were new Exadata or Exalogic. 
Third, our industry-focused solutions are increasing in relevance to customers and that shows up in our 17% growth but our industry focused solutions again grew faster than Oracle did in license growth. So again, good help from the industry-focused solutions. 
Now fourth I want to make sure this point is clear. In addition to Exadata and Exalogic growth, our SPARC server products grew this quarter. We have growth in the core SPARC product line. Our strategy around high-intellectual property, high attach, high-margin solutions, that include Exadata, Exalogic and the SPARC server products is working. You're also beginning to see that show up in these industry market share figures that show us gaining shares. 
Last, we are continuing to we added 350 people to our sales organization in Q1. And with that, I'll turn it back over to Ken for your questions

headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark. Anthony, I think we can proceed now to the Q&A portion of the call.
componenttext: Thanks, Mark. Anthony, I think we can proceed now to the Q&A portion of the call.

headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] I will take our first question from Adam Holt with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] I will take our first question from Adam Holt with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: My question I guess is for Mark on the Hardware business. It's a 2-part question. First, where do you think you are in turning this business around? And what gives you confidence in the forward looking? And secondly along that line, how conservative do yo
componenttext: My question I guess is for Mark on the Hardware business. It's a 2-part question. First, where do you think you are in turning this business around? And what gives you confidence in the forward looking? And secondly along that line, how conservative do you think the Hardware guidance is for the second quarter?

headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I thought that Adam, we'll get into a lot of conservatism or optimism. The guidance is the guidance. I think second point, I think we're really not as focused to be very frank on the Hardware growth rate as we are on the point that I just made of gr
componenttext: Well, I thought that Adam, we'll get into a lot of conservatism or optimism. The guidance is the guidance. I think second point, I think we're really not as focused to be very frank on the Hardware growth rate as we are on the point that I just made of growing the right things in the product line. The things that are attributable to long-term profitability, long-term positioning of the customer, long-term positioning in the datacenter. And I'll give you an example. If you take that core server product line that we grew in the quarter plus SPARC server product line, if you took the M-Series product, just imagine, Adam, that we sold $100 million worth of M-series products. And these are rough numbers. My guess over 5 years, our profitability on that is roughly $100 million when you include the attach and support and the service. Just the same, if we sold $100 million of X86 with no intellectual property, my guess, our profitability would be less than 1/5 of that. And I only bring that up to give you the polarization of the impact of intellectual property, the alignment of the intellectual property to the solution, the alignment of that to support the ability for us to do things for the customer and the eventual profitability for the company. So what we're focused on are the solutions like what Larry described are coming out, Exadata, Exalogic, the core SPARC product line and that's what we're focused. And in that context, I think we are turning around the business. I think you are seeing some of the momentum. And if you see the market turns data to show you the facts that we are gaining share in that core part of the product line.

headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let me at a little bit of that just so we're clear. I don't care if our commodity X86 business goes to 0. We don't make any money selling those things. We have no interest in selling other people's IT. Commodity x86 includes Intel IT and Microsoft IT. We
componenttext: Let me at a little bit of that just so we're clear. I don't care if our commodity X86 business goes to 0. We don't make any money selling those things. We have no interest in selling other people's IT. Commodity x86 includes Intel IT and Microsoft IT. We don't make money selling that. Sun filled that stuff and we are phasing out that business. We have no interest in it whatsoever. We have interest in selling systems that include our IT. That's how we're going to drive the profitability of our overall Hardware business. Eventually, I think that should in fairly short order, our engineered systems will be up growing at such a high rate that the overall Hardware business topline will grow also. But what's really important is continuously grow our margins in Hardware business and our profitability in Hardware business so we can meet Safra's goal which is getting back to our pre-Sun acquisition overall profit margins. Next question?

headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Heather Bellini with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Heather Bellini with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is a question for Larry. I was just wondering if you could walk us through the big data opportunity that everyone has been talking about and how you see Oracle participating in this trend and also how you see it impacting Oracle's core database franc
componenttext: This is a question for Larry. I was just wondering if you could walk us through the big data opportunity that everyone has been talking about and how you see Oracle participating in this trend and also how you see it impacting Oracle's core database franchise.

headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, Hadoop and all the associated utilities, which Hadoop which uses the term big data for all of that is going to be one of the feeder systems to the Oracle Database. We have announced interfaces that allow you to take your Hadoop systems and connect t
componenttext: Well, Hadoop and all the associated utilities, which Hadoop which uses the term big data for all of that is going to be one of the feeder systems to the Oracle Database. We have announced interfaces that allow you to take your Hadoop systems and connect them to Oracle system so you can load your Hadoop data into Oracle so we think it's going to increase the usage of Oracle. Furthermore, I'm not sure we're going to come up with 4 new intersystems, one of which is about superclusters and we're also going to have a big data engineering system that we're going to introduce at Oracle OpenWorld. So we think as more and more data gets computer on, a lot of that data finds its way into an Oracle Database and the cloud database business is to grow in an accelerated rate.

headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from John DiFucci with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question will come from John DiFucci with JPMorgan.

headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: My question first is a macro question. Safra, we've spoken for a while now about Europe. I know you have acknowledged sort of a macro weakness in the region, the same kind of stuff we're reading in the paper about. You continue to put a better result than
componenttext: My question first is a macro question. Safra, we've spoken for a while now about Europe. I know you have acknowledged sort of a macro weakness in the region, the same kind of stuff we're reading in the paper about. You continue to put a better result than we would expect but especially relative to others and actually especially this quarter. I guess can you talk a bit about what you're seeing in Europe more specifically and what might be implied for the guidance for the region?

headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, listen. Our bottom line is that I think we're being successful where other folks are being less successful because our products are so compelling. We had many, many orders in Europe for really sort of across the board for our product line because ei
componenttext: Well, listen. Our bottom line is that I think we're being successful where other folks are being less successful because our products are so compelling. We had many, many orders in Europe for really sort of across the board for our product line because either engineered systems or our other products are extremely compelling value propositions and it gives the customers an opportunity to be much more efficient. We were strong in really all the sectors that you may be reading about are struggling, both in Europe and in the United States. Our U.S. Government business is still very good. Our Financial Services businesses very good. Our European Business Banking business remains very good. So I'll tell you, I think we have a lot of company-specific momentum across the board. And that's really all I ever speak to is our own company. Mark, why don't you add some additional detail?

headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: At this point, so it is right we just saw the quarter in Europe. We did not see any anomaly that was unique across any other region that we had. We had some really cool business that showed up in Europe too. We had some great wins at Deutsche Post with Ex
componenttext: At this point, so it is right we just saw the quarter in Europe. We did not see any anomaly that was unique across any other region that we had. We had some really cool business that showed up in Europe too. We had some great wins at Deutsche Post with Exadata, Exalogic. We had some great Apps to Disc wins in the Europe in the quarter. I gave you the Applications growth number, 60%. I would be cautious to Safra's point that this is not maybe macro but may be more Oracle specific. We got a great team over there. And to add to it, we are hiring in Europe right now. We are adding to our sales force in Europe right now. We think there's more market to cover and there's more opportunity to go get. I guess I'd say it another way maybe a bit of a plug, I'm a very proud of those guys. They're doing a very good job they are gaining share and Exadata quarter was frankly very impressive as well.

headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Mark just a quick follow up to the point you made, you said the industry-focused solutions was really strong this quarter and Apps were really strong in Europe even though it was a relatively easy comps, it really looks like a really good number. Is that
componenttext: Mark just a quick follow up to the point you made, you said the industry-focused solutions was really strong this quarter and Apps were really strong in Europe even though it was a relatively easy comps, it really looks like a really good number. Is that at least partially due to industry vertical apps.

headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's all of the above. I would not leap to that conclusion, Jonathan. Think of it as broad-based again, very good quarter in the core Apps as well. So if you look at CRM, it was a very good quarter in Europe. Europe really just had a very good quarter sor
componenttext: It's all of the above. I would not leap to that conclusion, Jonathan. Think of it as broad-based again, very good quarter in the core Apps as well. So if you look at CRM, it was a very good quarter in Europe. Europe really just had a very good quarter sort of all the way around. I went to Exadata, very strong quarter. Good Exalogic quarter, good horizontal Apps quarter, good vertical apps quarter. We had a couple of apps of disc wins I described a little while ago. In fact that means end-to-end Oracle stack that we bring to the customers. So I wouldn't leap that it was any one thing. The best news I can tell you about Europe, broad-based.

headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll hear next from Phil Winslow with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: We'll hear next from Phil Winslow with Credit Suisse.

headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Another great quarter. Just posting back on that Applications one in particular, I believe it was 19% year-over-year in constant currency, which is pretty fantastic just given the environment and I do believe that it is largely organic. What is really dri
componenttext: Another great quarter. Just posting back on that Applications one in particular, I believe it was 19% year-over-year in constant currency, which is pretty fantastic just given the environment and I do believe that it is largely organic. What is really driving that especially kind of relative to your competitors? And also, Larry, just specifically the Fusion Applications. Just wondering if you can give us an update there as some of the feedback you're seeing maybe just help The Wall Street community here comparison in the Fusion architecture with some of the more legacy ones you see out of your competitors?

headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, as you know, we've been working for Fusion Apps for almost 6 years now and we have about 200 customers using Fusion Apps. We're going generally, before the end of this calendar year, we're going to have general availability on Fusion and we have a n
componenttext: Well, as you know, we've been working for Fusion Apps for almost 6 years now and we have about 200 customers using Fusion Apps. We're going generally, before the end of this calendar year, we're going to have general availability on Fusion and we have a number of wins against not only SAP using Fusion but some of the newer competitors like Workday using Fusion where people has compared to various interface, our SaaS offering to their SaaS offering, our cloud infrastructure to their cloud infrastructure. So we think it's very important that we're out in the market now, not only with our traditional applications, which will continue to support for years to come but also an all new generation of Fusion Applications, something that SAP, our largest applications competitor have. We think that is such a huge advantage going forward. Mark, do you want to add to that?

headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. I would add I think to Larry's point, I think we had a very good quarter across when you think about the Fusion base. I understand numbers and none of them stand out. They're all good. They're all growth numbers. And again, it's pretty broad-based a
componenttext: Sure. I would add I think to Larry's point, I think we had a very good quarter across when you think about the Fusion base. I understand numbers and none of them stand out. They're all good. They're all growth numbers. And again, it's pretty broad-based across ERP and EPM and CRM and so forth as well as the Vertical Application. I think when you have to add to Larry's point is we're the only company now with a series of traditional apps that are also bringing online our SaaS cloud Apps. We're in the market aggressively with HCM today. We've released that in Q4. We have teams dedicated to growing our Cloud business. We are doing the same thing now in CRM. You will see us very aggressively in the market, focused on those 2 segments as we move into Q2.

headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Brent Thill with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Brent Thill with UBS.

headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Two quick put questions, one for Larry and market just around the Database business. There's been a lot of focus on structured data and maybe at a time to Heather's question around kind of the next leg of growth for the database business, how do you think
componenttext: Two quick put questions, one for Larry and market just around the Database business. There's been a lot of focus on structured data and maybe at a time to Heather's question around kind of the next leg of growth for the database business, how do you think about that and where are you positioned around the new structured? And for Safra, just a lot of questions around financial and federal exposure. I don't know if you can give us a sense of what the exposure is and if you can give the specific numbers and if you can just kind of give us a ballpark because there's certainly a lot of attention on those 2 particular segments.

headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Oracle is always historic but structured and unstructured data. This is really nothing new. We are constantly adding features to our database to support the storage and searching of unstructured as well as a structured data. Our economy was a shock
componenttext: Okay. Oracle is always historic but structured and unstructured data. This is really nothing new. We are constantly adding features to our database to support the storage and searching of unstructured as well as a structured data. Our economy was a shock to us. We looked at the price thought it was certainly high. We have no interest in making it the economy acquisition. We think we're much better off to a couple smaller acquisitions and to continue to innovate in that area so that the unstructured data and the structured data both find their way into an Oracle Database, where it's a secured, it's scalable, it runs on Exadata. We think we really don't want to have 2 separate databases kind of autonomy like on a structured database and Oracle structured data. I think that data should be integrated with a single database technology. That's always been our strategy for Oracle. And it started as a relational database then we added objects, then we added text and we added a variety of other things like video and audio to deal with the Oracle Database. We think that's beautified and how we're approaching the problem. Mark?

headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, just add to it that again as you can see, our Database business grew in the quarter materially. I mean it was a very nice performance across our options, across additions. It was just strong. And I think the fact that you've gotten not only unstructu
componenttext: Yes, just add to it that again as you can see, our Database business grew in the quarter materially. I mean it was a very nice performance across our options, across additions. It was just strong. And I think the fact that you've gotten not only unstructured data, not only the data. You're going to have several million people now running around the planet with computers in their hands trying to get information out of databases. And we think that's good news for people without database like us because it's going to be a lot of people try to get information, simultaneously looking for performance. I think we'd look over the next several years, the database is going to continue to grow. The ability to direct database performance with capabilities like Exadata and Supercluster as Larry talked about earlier, aren't going to become as much a novelty as they are a requirement for all the people are going to try and get an opportunity to get this data. So database business performed well and the quarter and customers feel well positioned for all the secular trends going on in the world today.

headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Regarding the sectors in which we are big, luckily for us, we're sort of big in every segment. And telecommunications providers governments both federal, state and local, et cetera, banking, I would say to be honest with you that we don't have nearly the
componenttext: Regarding the sectors in which we are big, luckily for us, we're sort of big in every segment. And telecommunications providers governments both federal, state and local, et cetera, banking, I would say to be honest with you that we don't have nearly the exposure that banking -- I think there still remains an enormous opportunity in the banking sector for much more Oracle than there is now. Historically, they are a much more mainframe-focused segment. And we actually have opportunity because we run much, much faster. We're much, much cheaper to operate and over time, I think that remains an opportunity. I don't view it at all as exposure. I think it explains by the way why even with the sector under pressure, we continue to grow so much because our products are just better. We are a very good fit and we continue to do well in all these segments.

headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: To add to it to. When you look at the play with the Exa line, it is every bit as much as a consolidation play. So when you think of an industry like financial services, that Exadata delivers performance and it also delivers economies. So the opportunity f
componenttext: To add to it to. When you look at the play with the Exa line, it is every bit as much as a consolidation play. So when you think of an industry like financial services, that Exadata delivers performance and it also delivers economies. So the opportunity for us to go into a bank and deliver any ability to the bank to dial on the continuum and how much performance you want and how much cost do you want to reduce. So we have customers in banking where I think to Safra's point, we have tremendous opportunity to go into those banks and have them consolidate Oracle on Oracle and either again performance or actually save money simultaneously. That's a very attractive value proposition in this kind of economy and an opportunity for us.

headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jason Maynard with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jason Maynard with Wells Fargo.

headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: I wonder if you could go back to the Hardware business. And if you can give me a little context or framing around where you think you're adding your transformation to selling engineering systems and maybe talk about it on customer adoption and then also j
componenttext: I wonder if you could go back to the Hardware business. And if you can give me a little context or framing around where you think you're adding your transformation to selling engineering systems and maybe talk about it on customer adoption and then also just in terms of the organizational capacity, shifting more from an engineered or to engineered systems from some of the legacies and Hardware products?

headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean I'll tackle title that. I think certainly next, we would expect our overall Hardware business to have topline growth, no question about it. And the transition right now is we've got -- our axle line up almost doubled in the quarter in Q1. Our
componenttext: Well, I mean I'll tackle title that. I think certainly next, we would expect our overall Hardware business to have topline growth, no question about it. And the transition right now is we've got -- our axle line up almost doubled in the quarter in Q1. Our overall SPARC line was up. Our servers, our x86 line commodity line was down and Sun had to practice. It's selling x86 at very, very low margins. And we reward our salespeople based on margins. So we don't make money selling low-margin commodity x86 boxes and our salespeople don't make any money selling them. And therefore, we're deemphasizing that business. That business is shrinking. However, our profitable businesses in servers, the Exa line and the SPARC line are growing. And also, our storage, the system is growing. Our polar system is growing. The Exadata system storage is growing. So our disc storage systems are all growing, the ones with our IT. However, we also sell third-party disks without our IT at very low margins. Those are still in the system. And we expect those low-margin storage systems to also decline because again, we pay our salespeople based on margins and there is no margin. There's very low margin on those products. We don't care about selling those products because we don't make any money. I think your question is when will we sell -- when will that be out of the system. And that's pretty much only selling servers or storage with our IP and I think that will be next fiscal year you'll see topline growth in the Hardware business. But this fiscal year, you'll see continued improvement in gross margin and continued improvement in profitability in our overall Hardware business, the commodity this will gradually shrinking every quarter. I don't know if I answered your question.

headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: And our last question comes from Kash Rangan from Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: And our last question comes from Kash Rangan from Merrill Lynch.

headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: One for Larry, one for Mark. Larry, I remember about a year back, we asked you about big data on this conference call. And just a follow-up to that, you have 2 new systems or 4 new engineered systems launching. One of them of them the big data engineer sy
componenttext: One for Larry, one for Mark. Larry, I remember about a year back, we asked you about big data on this conference call. And just a follow-up to that, you have 2 new systems or 4 new engineered systems launching. One of them of them the big data engineer system and also I think you mentioned Exadata Flash-based system. I'm curious, if we should think about the market that you're growing up and is there still core business or are you trying to go after other alternative approaches to the core market? And then I have a follow-up question for Mark.

headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Let might be clear on the. I mean Oracle has not just been a, for about 20 years. We added I don't know how many people are on the call are my age probably. But a long time ago, after relational databases came out, there is a next-generation databas
componenttext: Okay. Let might be clear on the. I mean Oracle has not just been a, for about 20 years. We added I don't know how many people are on the call are my age probably. But a long time ago, after relational databases came out, there is a next-generation database so-called object database. And I'm not going to talk about what other databases are going to replace relational database. And what actually happened is that object database capabilities got integrated into the Oracle Database so Oracle just the relational database with database. And then when there is thing called text databases or text search. And those were separate databases and Oracle then incorporated a text search, text capability into the Oracle Database. And then there were these things called XML databases and separate XML databases and Oracle integrated XML capability. And now people are talking a lot about unstructured data and things like autonomy. Oracle's strategy has always been to integrate additional types of data into the Oracle Database. And a lot of it is unstructured data whether it's video or audio or images, all of those. We think the transition continues. We started relational then object then text then XML. Now a lot of different types of unstructured data types all going into the Oracle databases. Finally, big data or the searching of large amounts of data Hadoop. After had to finish as filtering the data, the place you want to put that data is in Oracle Database and that's what a lot of our customers are doing. And we are exploiting the trend, the big data technology and the big data trend, if you prefer, by building a Hadoop appliance that attaches to the Oracle Exadata database or any Oracle Database for that matter. But you don't have to buy a Hadoop plan, you can use whatever servers you want running Hadoop and we provide the interface between Hadoop and the Oracle Database. The idea is all of your data should be -- you should be able to put all of your data regardless of data type into the Oracle Database where it can be stored securely and reliably. And you could search it and that answers your question very quickly.

headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: And Mark, on the last quarter conference call on the press release, you said that you hoped to triple the install base of Exadata in the fiscal year. Just wondering if you still feel that cyclical? That's it for me.
componenttext: And Mark, on the last quarter conference call on the press release, you said that you hoped to triple the install base of Exadata in the fiscal year. Just wondering if you still feel that cyclical? That's it for me.

headline: Oracle Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: And we think we got pipeline and a product line that puts us in a position to get that done. And I think to Larry's point, we are also having a lot more products than the Lab. When we look at what we're going to released a couple weeks at Oracle OpenWorld
componenttext: And we think we got pipeline and a product line that puts us in a position to get that done. And I think to Larry's point, we are also having a lot more products than the Lab. When we look at what we're going to released a couple weeks at Oracle OpenWorld, some of which you heard about today. Tomorrow, you'll see us release an engineered system that combines more Oracle IP together to serve yet another part of the market. We just feel very good about our more to broader engineered systems line and certainly specifically in the Exa so that's what we're trying to get done.
